Package de.oth.blocklib.world.vegetation

Class Turtle

java.lang.Object
de.oth.blocklib.world.vegetation.Turtle
public class Turtle
extends java.lang.Object
This class is used to represent a String, created from a L-System, in the Blocklib world. It saves the position and the blockid in a hashmap, which can be used to plant the tree in the world. Currently its only possible to do 2D turtle movements. The third dimension is not yet implemented
Author:
Julian Sellner

    • Turtle

      Parameters:
      interaction - PopulatingWorldInteraction to set and get blocks
      startVector - The vector where the turtle starts
      blockId - The blockId which will be used
      sentence - The sentence which the turtle has to go trough

      interaction - PopulatingWorldInteraction to set and get blocks
      startVector - The vector where the turtle starts
      blockIds - List of BlockIds
      sentence - The sentence which the turtle has to go trough

  • Method Details

    • turtle

      public Vector3i turtle()
      Main component of the class. This function iterates trough the sentence at looks at every char. Depending on the char the turtle makes different decisions;
      • F: The current position in the coordinate system will be saved in the map and the turtle moves forward
      • f: Move without placing blocks
      • +/-: Turn the turtle right/left
      • [: Save the current position of the turtle in a stack
      • ]: return the saved position from the stack
      • *: places a block in the current position
      • <: move upwards
      • >: move downwards
      • #: change blockId

    • setBlockHere

      private void setBlockHere()

      private void turnRight()

    • turnLeft

      private void turnLeft()

    • rotate

      public void rotate​(int rotationAngle)
      This rotates the turtle in different directions. Since the turtle can only move forward, the direction has to be adjusted depending on the rotationAngle
      Parameters:
      rotationAngle - This will either be a positive or negative value. Positive meaning its turning to the right and negative meaning its turning to the left.

    • moveForward

      private void moveForward()
      Depending on the direction, the turtle moves different in the coordinate system
